text:
180-182 Fulton Street, west side, between Cranberry and Orange Streets. The Brooklyn Museum, a theatre, was opened in the central building, in 1850, but it was a failure. Washington Council No. 1, order of United American Mechanics opened its lodge rooms in the Cary Building, at the left, May 15, 1849. These buildings were demolished after considerable damage by fire in 1923.

About 1896.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)

246-262 Fulton Street, west side, between Clark and Clinton Streets. The view shows at the right the establishment of Ovington Bros., sellers of Chinaware. The center building, known as a hotel was originally the Globe (1856), later the Eagle (1893), and in recent time the Commercial Hotel.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same, showing more in the left foreground. Also seen in both views is the elevated structure of the B.M.T.

April 13, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

246-262 Fulton Street, west side, between Clark and Clinton Streets. The view shows at the right the establishment of Ovington Bros., sellers of Chinaware. The center building, known as a hotel was originally the Globe (1856), later the Eagle (1893), and in recent time the Commercial Hotel.

(2)

The same, showing more in the left foreground. Also seen in both views is the elevated structure of the B.M.T.

April 13, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

246-254 Fulton Street, west side, between Clark and Clinton Streets. At the right is the former Ovington Bros., Gift Shop. This firm is now on Fifth Ave., (Manhattan). June 1926.

Brown Brothers.

186-200 Fulton Street, between Nassau (right), and Pineapple Streets, showing the Fulton Street elevated lines, as seen across clearing, from Nassau at Liberty Streets. In the background is the Hotel St. George. Also shown, is a view westward on the south side of Nassau Street, which becomes Orange Street after it crosses Fulton Street.

April 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
